About

Brian Bonus

Web dev, amateur chef, and UCLA grad.

His career in software started after winning a coding competition and hasn't looked back since. While his primary focus is the front end, he has experience working in Rails, ruby and some Python in the mix. He regrets trying Java. Lately he's been busy with Backbone, Angular, SASS and Yeoman/Grunt/Bower.

When he's not coding or rounding out his CS fundamentals, he's probably busy hiking, biking or messing around with an old saxophone.

He likes making things and writing in the third person.

Work

Before

hitRECord UI update

I led the effort to update hitRECord's UI per designer mocks and a general desire for responsive design. While not entirely responsive yet, the new design (right), is more playful and allow for greater usability of core functionality. A side benefit of this re-design was the opportunity to further optimize page load times and started the move from backbone.js towards angular.js

After

PocketWatch

An experiment with Meteor.js, MongoDB and a series of financial and political APIs, PocketWatch is a prototype for a anti-corruption tool. Motivated from the recent scandal in the city of Bell, we believe open data and citizen hacktivism has the potential to help improve cities for all of us. In our app, users can see the connections between campaign contributions, political officials, and city contracts.

A friend and I won 1st Place Overall App at the Hack4LA Hackathon with this project. Big thanks to Socrata for sponsoring!

Glassroom GTV

My first hackathon. Ever. It was equal parts terrifying and exhilirating. I was learning Rails and Backbone on the fly while trying to contribute to a classroom teaching tool that incorporated the Youtube API.

We took 1st place for teamwork, thanks google!

Not Work

Travel.

I'm not sure it's a hobby, or something more, but I get a little anxious if I don't travel frequently.

I love interesting food and new places. Which means I'm a bit of a hedonist (see food porn below). Travelling is easily the best way to expand your personal horizons and change your perspective. It protects against insularity, racism, and fosters sympathy for other people.

So yeah, of course we come back with stories of late night fish-n-chips, wine and tapas or maybe deep-dish pizza, but I think it's the conscious choice to interrupt routines that make those meals and moments what they are.
